questions.text: A 59-year-old male hypertensive visited the doctor for routine checkup. On auscultation doctor heard diastolic murmur well near the aortic area. This murmur is probably due to?
questions.solution:
• Aortic murmurs are best heard in aortic region as shown in figure.
  • Mitral valve murmurs are best heard near the apex of the heart.
  • Systolic murmur best heard in mitral area occurs due to mitral regurgitation.
  • Ventricular diastolic murmur best heard in mitral area are due to mitral stenosis.
  • Patent ductus arteriosus murmurs are continuous heard in systole and diastole

Tag: Cardiac cycle

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1230 Table 30-2

questions.text: The sympathetic system influences the activity of heart via T1 to T5 segments of the spinal cord. Its stimulation causes increase in activity of heart. Increase in heart rate so called
questions.solution:
• T1 to T5 segments of the spinal cord give sympathetic output to the heart. The increase in sympathetic stimulation increases the activities of heart like force of contraction, heart rate, excitability of heart and also conductivity in the heart.
  • Increase in force of contraction (effect on heart muscle) is known as ionotropic action on the heart. It increases stroke volume and thus cardiac output.
  • Increase in heart rate with sympathetic stimulation (via pacemaker stimulation) is known as chronotropic action.
  • Increase in excitability of heart is known as positive bathmotropic action of heart.
  • Increase in rate of conduction of impulse is called as dromotropic action on the heart.
  • Vagus gives parasympathetic supply to heart. It produces decrease in heart activity.

Tag: Regulation

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number:1235

choices.text: Decrease in local concentration Of CO2

questions.text: Among the list of the following factors which does not increase the coronary blood flow?
questions.solution:
• The coronary blood flow is not only influenced by the pressure changes but also by some neural and chemical factors. It helps in autoregulation of the blood flow.
  • Following factors increases the coronary blood flow
    • Lack of oxygen (hypoxia)(Option D)
    • Increase level of metabolites (CO2, H+, K+, lactate)
    • Increase in adenosine(Option A)
    • Increase in prostaglandins
    • Asphyxia
    • Intracoronary injection of cyanide(Option B)
    • Occlusion followed by release of coronary blood flow (reactive hyperemia)

Tag: Circulation

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number:1393,1394

questions.text: 26-year-old male appearing for fitness for new insurance policy. The image below shows his ECG recording. Calculate the heart rate per minute from below ECG.
questions.solution:
• ECG can be used to calculate the heart rate.
  • We use either R-R interval or P-P interval to calculate heart rate.
  • It can be calculated via dividing 1500 by number of small squares in R-R interval or P-P interval or via dividing 300 by number of large squares in R-R interval or P-P interval.
  • 1500/ 19 small squares = 78
  • 300/3.6 large squares = 83
  • So, the answer is heart rate falls between 75 to 85 per minute

Tag: ECG

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed page number.136- 137

questions.text: In normal tidal expiration which muscle contraction occurs?
questions.solution:
• Normal tidal expiration is a passive process that occurs due to elastic recoil of the lungs, decrease in size of thorax due to relaxation of diaphragm and external intercostal muscles and increase in tone of muscles of anterior abdominal wall.
  • During forced expiration following muscles are used
  • Abdominal muscles (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, internal oblique) and Internal intercostal muscles
  • Normal tidal inspiration is an active process.
    75% of tidal inspiration occurs due to diaphragm and remaining occurs due to external intercostal muscles.

Tag: Mechanics of ventilation

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number.1425

questions.text: The image below shows Uptake of various substances during the 0.75 s they are in transit through a pulmonary capillary. Here the Transport of N2O is
questions.solution:
• Nitrous oxide (N2O) does not react and reaches equilibrium in about 0.1 s. The amount of N2O taken up is not limited by diffusion but by the amount of blood flowing through the pulmonary capillaries; that is, it is flow-limited.
  • Carbon monoxide (CO) is taken up by hemoglobin in the red blood cells at such a high rate that the partial pressure of CO in the capillaries stays very low and equilibrium is not reached in the 0.75 s the blood is in the pulmonary capillaries. So the CO transfer is diffusion limited.(Option C)
  • O2 it is taken up by hemoglobin, but much less avidly than CO, and it reaches equilibrium with capillary blood in about 0.3 s. Thus, its uptake is perfusion limited.(Option A)

Tag: Diffusion

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number.1447

questions.text: P50 that is partial pressure at 50% hemoglobin saturation with oxygen. Which factor/s from the list cause/s increase in P50?
questions.solution:
• P50 is the partial pressure of o2 that produces a 50% saturation of the Hb with o2 Normal P50 for arterial blood at 37°C body temperature and at pCO2 of blood 40 mmhg is 25-27 mmhg.
  • Hb affinity for o2 is inversely related to the p50 value.
  • 2,3-DPG is abundant in red cells. It is formed from 3- phosphoglyceraldehyde, which is a product of glycolysis via the Embden-Meyerhof pathway. It binds to beta chain in deoxygenated haemoglobin reduces the affinity for haemoglobin with oxygen.
  • At equilibrium increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG shifts the Hb-O2 dissociation curve to the right, causing more O2 to be liberated.
  • Following causes increase in P50
    • Thyroid hormones,
    • Androgens,
    • Growth hormones
    • Exercise
    • increase in 2-3 DPG conc
    • Rise in temperature
  • Decrease in P50
    • Acidosis (inhibits red cell glycolysis)
    • Fall in 2,3 DPG

Tag: Oxygen transport

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1466.

questions.text: A 34year-old male has significant heart burn. He visited primary care physician for it. On investigation it is found that his stomach secretes excessive HCL. Which of the following receptor antagonist is useful in the treatment?
questions.solution:
• Neurotransmitter histamine is formed by decarboxylation of the amino acid histidine.
  • It acts on three type of receptors.
  • H1 receptors: In airways, vascular smooth muscle
  • H2 receptors: found on parietal cells which secrete HCl.
  • H3 receptors: primarily in the brain.
  • H2 receptor antagonists are used to reduce the secretion of HCl in the stomach. H2 blockers are ranitidine, famotidine, cimetidine etc.
  • H1- receptor antagonists on the market include loratadine, fexofenadine, cetirizine, and desloratadine. They are used to reduce the allergic response.

Tag: Stomach

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 158.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is not activated by Trypsin?
questions.solution:
• Trypsin is an enzyme secreted from the pancreas as an inactive trypsinogen. It is protein digesting enzyme activated by enterokinase enzyme from the small intestine.
  • Functions of trypsin are
    • It converts chymotrypsinogen to chymotrypsin. Chymotrypsin is an already activated enzyme, it does not need trypsin. It is an endopeptidase.
    • It converts procarboxypeptidase to carboxypeptidase which is an exopeptidase.
    • It also activates trypsinogen.
    • Trypsin, chymotrypsin and carboxypeptidase digest the protein in the small intestine.
    • Trypsin also activates phospholipase A2. This enzyme splits a fatty acid off phosphatidylcholine (PC).

Tag: Pancreatic juice

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1062,1101.

choices.text: Some Bile acids are absorbed by nonionic diffusion
Major portion of bile acid is absorbed by ABST
Some absorbed in the form of deoxycholate in the colon

questions.text: What is the fate of bile after secretion in the small intestine?
questions.solution:
• Bile is formed in the liver and secreted in the second part of duodenum along with pancreatic secretion.
  • It is very important for digestion and absorption of lipids in the small intestine.
  • 90 to 95% of bile acids are absorbed from small intestine in two ways.
    • In deconjugated form bile acids are absorbed by nonionic diffusion in the small intestine. It is in small amount.
    • Majority is absorbed in conjugated form in the terminal ileum by an extremely efficient Na+-bile salt cotransport system (ABST). Its activity is driven by the low intracellular sodium concentration established by the basolateral Na+, K+ ATPase.
    • The remaining 5 to 10 % enter in the colon. Here it is converted to the salts of deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid.
      • Lithocholate is insoluble and excreted in stool.
      • Deoxycholate is absorbed in colon.

Tag: Bile

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1066.

questions.text: Calculate the total peripheral resistance from the below diagram. Here R1=R2=R3=R4=5mmHg/ml/min.
questions.solution:
• Understanding the resistance
    1. Resistance in series is
      R= R1+R2+R3+…… Rn
    2. Resistance in parallel vessels
      1/R =1/R1 +1/R2 +1/R3+…… 1/Rn
  • Here the vessels run in parallel to each other.
  • 1/TPR = 1/R1 +1/R2 +1/R3 + 1/R4
    1/TPR = 1/5 +1/5 +1/5 +1/5 = 4/5
  • TPR (total peripheral resistance) = 5/4 = 0.2 mmHG/ml/min
  • Correct answer is a

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed page number.177 fig. 14-9

choices.text: Starting of carotid pressure rise to the dicrotic notch
QRS complex to the closure of aortic valves

questions.text: A physician advised 71-year-old female to check about her left ventricular function. The duration of electromechanical systole-QS2 in left ventricle gives idea about?
questions.solution:
• To measure about duration of isovolumetric ventricular contraction is difficult in cardiac disorders.
  • The duration of total electromechanical systole (QS2), the pre-ejection period (PEP), and the left ventricular ejection time (LVET) will help to identify the left ventricular contractile function. It is measured by recording the ECG, phonocardiogram, and carotid pulse simultaneously.
  • QS2 is the period from the onset of the QRS complex to the closure of the aortic valves, as determined by the onset of the second heart sound.
  • LVET is the period from the beginning of the carotid pressure rise to the dicrotic notch.
  • PEP is the difference between QS2 and LVET and represents the time for the electrical as well as the mechanical events that precede systolic ejection.
  • Ventricular filling occurs after QRS complex ends. It is between 1st and 2nd heart sound.
  • The ratio of PEP/LVET increases when left ventricular performance is compromised. Normally it is 0.35.

Topic : ECG

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number.1227,1228

questions.text: A 26- year-old patient met with an accident. He lost more than 25 % blood loss. Doctor prescribed the treatment for hemorrhagic shock. Which of the following will probably help in case of hemorrhagic shock?
questions.solution:
• Dextran is a plasma substitute that increases the volume of plasma when administered in the blood vessel. It is definitely of help in hemorrhagic shock.
  • Calcium channel blockers are used to reduce the blood pressure by causing vasodilatation.
    • This drug causes further detrimental effect in hemorrhagic shock by blood pressure reduction.
  • Glucocorticoid are helpful in all stages of shock as it increases the strength of the heart in the late stages of shock; stabilize the lysosomal cells.
  • Sympathomimetic drugs are not to be very valuable in hemorrhagic shock.
    • Here the sympathetic nervous system is already maximally activated by regulatory mechanisms. So there is no additional benefit of it.

Topic: Circulation Hemodynamics

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 3rd south Asian edition Page number.301

choices.text: It relaxes the sphincter of oddi
It is secreted from C cells in the small intestine
It increases the formation of bile

questions.text: Cholecystokinin is a hormone secreted in the gastrointestinal tract. Following is true about it.
questions.solution:
• Cholecystokinin hormone is secreted from I cells of the mucosa of upper small intestine. Statement b in not true
  • Following are the function of CCK in GIT
    • It contracts gall bladder to release stored concentrated bile from the gall bladder in response to the food in the duodenum.
    • It stimulates the pancreatic enzyme secretion to improve digestion.
    • It relaxes sphincter of oddi. This sphincter is present in the second part of duodenum. It allows the content of hepatopancreatic duct to enter in the small intestine. Normally when intestine is empty, the sphincter is closed. When open, it allows both bile and pancreatic juice to flow into the intestinal lumen.
    • It also contracts the pyloric sphincter to reduce the gastric emptying.
    • CCK augments the action of secretin in producing secretion of an alkaline pancreatic juice.
  • Bile is formed in the liver. It does not have any effect on bile formation. Its secretion increases the bile content in the small intestine.
  • CCK is found in nerves in the distal ileum and colon. It is also found in neurons in the brain, especially the cerebral cortex.

Topic: Bile

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1072,1073.

choices.text: It helps to reduce the effect of inhalation of toxic gases
It reduces the work of breathing

questions.text: Among the following list which is advantage of functional residual capacity?
questions.solution:
• Functional residual capacity is the air remaining in the lungs after normal expiration.
  • It is residual volume + expiratory reserve volume = 2300 ml in normal average adults.
  • Following are the benefits of FRC
    1. Continuous exchange of gases is possible
    2. Breath holding is possible
    3. Dilution of toxic inhaled gases
    4. Decreases load on respiratory mechanism and left ventricle
  • Hyperinflation of lungs increases FRC
    • in old age
    • emphysema
    • bronchial asthma

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 495, 496
